title: Towards Annotating Potential Incoherences in BioPortal Mappings
segmentation: Hi, I'm Daniel from the University of Lisbon.

And I guess the title of my presentation is kind of self explanatory, so our goal is to extend bioportal by annotating mappings that cause logical incoherence is, and I'm basically going to try to convince you that this is a good idea.
So I'll start to talk a bit about the Y so present bioportal and the the reason why.
It's a good idea too.
Do note 8 in incoherence causing mappings.
Then about the how so how we can approach that and then present our evaluation on the scale of the problem and how helpful it would be too.
Annotate the incoherence causing mappings, and then discuss a bit what we're planning to do for the future.
So by Portal is perhaps the main hub for biomedical ontologies.
It currently contains.
I mean it did at the time of our study.
273 ontologies probably more now.
And it maintains mappings between them, most of which are automatically generated using a lexical matcher, so it contains upwards of 313 million mappings nowadays.
And mappings are represented.
So as a four tuple relating the two entities and they have a relationship and annotation, the relationship can be one of these four.
So scores exact match when the entities have the same UI, exactly a close match is used for lexical machers and Umm, less mappings.

Related matches used for over cross references, and I mean it equates to less close relationship and then narrow match and broad match that currently can only be used in user submitted mappings I think.
When we submitted our work, one of the comments from the reviewers was why?
Where we assuming that this cost close match was all equivalent.
And I guess it's irrelevant question because because when we approached Ray Ferguson from bioportal, it was also one of the comments he made.

Well, Bioportal uses cost close match because they basically generate their mappings automatically so and they don't really want to be concerned with the exact semantics of or logical entailments of those mappings.

And The thing is, if you're actually going to use the mappings to integrate ontologies to to answer queries, then you have to make a stronger assumption because cost close match doesn't really have a semantic meaning, so you have to assume one way or another that you have equivalent classes in order to be able to cross between the ontologies.

So most users will implicitly or explicitly assume that the scores close matches correspond to equivalent classes, and therefore it's important to actually analyze the entailments generated by the close match mappings as if they were equivalent classes, and that's what we did in our study.
So I'll make a brief introduction about mapping, repair and.
So the key concept you have to take an Alexander already talked a bit about this is that when you integrate two ontologies through an alignment, you may obtain unsatisfiable classes.
So logical entailments that are undesired.
And happen even if everything is correct.

I mean, even if all the mappings are correct and the ontologies are correct, the biomedical domain is so complex that there are different ways to represent the and structure your domain in your classes, and you can often get cases like this where you end up with these classes are disjoint and by inheritance these classes are disjoint as well, and you have two mappings that.
Delete that map, match equivalent concepts and you get a disjointness violation.
So in this case it's really hard to.
I don't know how many of you are biomedical experts, but it's really hard to.
To say that anything is wrong, if that there's a wrong mapping or even the technologies are wrong.
One could argue that this disjointness is perhaps a bit too strict, but even then it's coherent with the ontologies design.
But more often than not.
In unsatisfiable classes and the mappings that cause them are assigned that there's something wrong.
So either the mapping itself is wrong or the ontologies are poorly designed, but in most cases it's useful to identify this and maybe correct it.
So there are three key concepts that that are essential to understand the presentation.
So when you coherent alignment is a set of mappings between two ontologies.
So the set of all mappings in, in this case between ontologies and it's a coherent if it causes unsatisfiable clauses.

A conflict set is a minimal subset of these mappings that is responsible for one or more related and satisfy abilities such that when you remove one mapping, you usually solve the unsatisfiability's and get a coherent alignment with regard to those classes.

And the process of mapping repair is of course to remove mappings from an incoherent alignment so as to increase or ensure its coherence, and the goal is typically to minimize the impact the procedure has on the alignment.
So to remove as few mappings as possible or as.
If you if your mappings have a confidence score, remove the smallest confidence mappings first, for instance.
So repair processes.
A hard computational process, so it's NP hard.
And and therefore there are few complete repair algorithms that analyzed all possible logical entailments and that ensure optimality.
So they remove the ideal minimal number of mappings.
But this is really not feasible for large ontologies such as most of the ontologies in the biomedical domain.
So to tackle large ontologies we have to make some approximations.
We have to decrease the number of logical entailments we analyzed.
Typically we focus on disjointness violations.
And.
It's also hard to ensure optimality, so usually have to adopt A eristic procedure to approximate the optimal repair.
So the two algorithms we used for repair in bioportal.

Where the agreement maker light repair algorithm, which is an approximate algorithm, it uses a global heuristic so it computes all conflict sets of mappings from an alignment and then resolve them approaching the optimal solution.

And we also used log map repair, which is also an approximate but uses a local heuristic so it resolves conflict sets individual for each unsatisfiable class so it detects unsatisfiable classes one at a time, and.
Then resolves the unsatisfiability for that class before proceeding to the next.
So they are nearly equivalent with respect to completeness.
And log map is of course more efficient.
It scales a bit better and.
AML repair is closer to optimality because it uses a global heuristic.
So we didn't start by applying our algorithms to the whole bioportal, and this is somewhat preliminary study.
So we picked the set of ontology pairs from my portal.
To illustrate the problem and see how feasible it was to tackle the problem using our repair algorithms.
So we selected 19 ontology pairs of ontologies that had a significantly sized alignments that had disjointness clauses.
Otherwise there was nothing to repair.
And that we're in the biomedical domain because we are.
Versed in in that domain and we wanted to analyze the resulting repairs.
So we found that out of these 19 ontology pairs, 11 had incoherent alignments in bioportal.
And we preceded to automatically repair these alignments using our repair systems.

So the goal of this evaluation was to assess how feasible it would be to use our repair systems to actually tackle this problem and how useful it it would be to be able to annotate bioportal mappings within using our systems.
So what we found is that we were able to resolve most of the unsatisfiable classes and produce coherent alignments in many cases.
And in the few cases that we didn't, there were just a few.
I mean in total, I think about one or two percent of the unsatisfiable classes were were left in this 11 ontology pairs.
So at this time, the email repair was a bit less complete than log map repair, but we have since improved it and they are now essentially equivalent with regard to completeness.

With regard to optimality, we found that the repairs were not very aggressive, so in the worst case of those 11 pairs, we moved 6 to 7% of the input mappings in a task where 61% of the mappings were involved in conflicts.
So.

We also found that this was really relevant in Bioportal, so 11 of the 19 alignments as I said were incoherent and on average of these incoherent alignments, 22% of the mappings were involved in conflict sets.
And in many cases there were key mappings that were involved in multiple and satisfy abilities.
So that is why we actually could remove only a small percentage of the mappings and resolve all the unsatisfiability's.

So and with regard to efficiency inefficiency, we found that both systems tackled even the largest taxi in at most a few minutes, which means that it's actually feasible to tackle the whole of bioportal using our.
Repair systems
So after performing the automatic repair analysis, we decided to analyze the mappings removed by the systems to really.
To really assess what was happening and.
In in the alignments and what we were removing, we found that in a significant number of cases we were removing ironias mappings and even in the cases where we weren't there were correct.
We removed correct mappings, but the the only thing was that the decision of the repair algorithm was wrong because there was an incorrect mapping in conflict with the correct mapping.
So theoretically we could have removed their honest mapping if the decision had gone the other way.
So to conclude.
Identifying incoherence cause causing mappings in in bioportal is critical.
I mean if if we want to integrate ontologies or to make queries across multiple ontologies, you need to have a coherent alignment.
And we found the during our analysis that is also helpful for finding potential errors in the mapping.

So many of the cases where we identify conflicts, there are erroneous mappings behind that, and flagging this annotating this would be helpful towards allowing users and creators to review the mappings and remove their nice ones.
Anne and we've shown that our approximate mapping repair systems are capable of tackling these problems and able to identify most logical conflicts.
So.
We've been in contact with Ferguson from my portal and our goal is ongoing to analyze all bioportal mappings and afterwards to integrate our findings into into by portal.

So extend by portal by storing and enable querying of annotations about the mappings involved in logical conflicts so that users can retrieve the mappings and maybe exclude those that are involved in conflicts if their applications so require it.

And to maintain the system up to date and also to enable some feedback upon new mapping entry, we want to develop a lightweight analyzer that is able to to analyze mapping submitted by the users and report in case of conflicts.
So there are a few challenges.
One of them will be precisely this this last goal.
So analyzing new mappings on the fly that involve huge ontologies such as Nomad will be hard.
And of course, the question is where do we stop?

So I've been talking about mappings between two ontologies, but we can have logical entailments between 3:00 or more ontologies that involve a string of different mappings that eventually go back to cause unsatisfiability's and.
I mean, in a complex mapping network such as bioportal, I mean it's a really tough problem and it will be an interesting challenge to tackle.
So that's it.
Thank you.
Yeah, so you essentially analyze the mapping as if it's an equivalence class relationship, right?
Exactly so would that make any difference in terms of the number of of of mapping errors?
If you consider instead subclass relationship, you know less restrictive than equivalence equivalence class.
Yeah, I mean, if you consider it a subclass for sure it will be.
It will be less less restrictive.
You have only One Direction to go, but The thing is for subclass relationships we have the scars, narrow match or broad match.
So we really think that the clothes match.
Most users will consider that it's an equivalence, and that's why we made that assumption.
I'm just surprised.
Everything in your in your study relies on the fact that you consider what they call exact match.
I will say my eyes and I mean no.
No close match.
Not exactly match.
Sorry on the I mean just making the I mean if that relation was used in the system and not I would say same as I mean those guys knows the difference between and this costs references.
Actually telling you as I said under suitable entailments that would follow from using our same as so they just don't use over same as because otherwise you will have in German.
So it's like yeah that's what I talked about in this slide I mean.
They don't use it because the mappings are automatically generated and they really cannot assume it.
But The thing is, if you are a user you want to integrate those ontologies you want to use the mappings from our portal to do something to make cross ontology.
Querying to integrate ontologies too.
I mean, if you want to use them in practice, you have to make this assumption, otherwise there's no semantic meaning in close match.
I mean, at least you cannot say that you are not aware of.
That that those are not exactly our same as mapping.
Yeah, there there they are not originally but but you have to assume it if you want to use them.
That's that's just our point, OK?
We're not taking away anything from Bio portal, so the mappings will still be close match.
If you're not concerned with logical incoherence.
If you don't want to make the assumption of our same as, then the mappings are still there.

What we're proposing is to wear the notation in the cases where you do want to make this assumption to use the mappings for some applications that do require logical coherence, so a good output will be actually to have from all the mappings, make a proposition that actually says those one can be considered as.
I would say Matt yeah and that's also mention that that's also one of the things that can come out of this study, and we actually discussed with Ray.
Yeah, just a slightly different follow up question.
In fact, I had a question for future work.
Yeah, in this case it would typically make sense to have a boat which is able to either transform this close match into equivalent classes or same as.
But in this case, would it make sense to instead of doing minimal repair, that is, to suppress one conflicting correspondence to only certify those who appear in no conflict at all?
Our goal is not to do repair.

OK, so our goal is to use the repair systems, but just to flag the mappings that are involved in conflicts were just trying to annotate mappings that are in conflict with one another so that the user can then choose to.
Not not pick up the conflicting mappings.
I mean we can suggest potential errors using the repair systems, but The thing is that in many cases the decision of the repair system is a bit arbitrary with regard to correctness.
I mean it doesn't have the biomedical background to make the decision of which mapping is more correct and which is wrong.
OK, so our goal is just to flag the conflicting mapping.
So this is basically already what you do.
And the next question is that you mentioned the difficulty to do globally with Bio Portal into final the conflict in the World, Bio Portal etc.
Then have you got an idea of the connectivity of this bio photograph?
That is, it's.
It's usually difficult if any ontology in bio portal is related to all the ontologies in biota.
But if there are clusters of ontologies, it may be a bit more practical.
Yeah, but even for for clusters of three or four ontologies, I mean, it's still it's still a big problem.
We still have to do some thinking about how we're going to extend the repair systems.
Yeah, but I don't think it's really all against all.
But there are a few large clusters.
Of ontologies in a few subdomains.
And it will be hard problem.
I like your idea of application specific needs rights for some.
For some applications, that the assumption that it is an exact match is actually a very good assumption, and for others it isn't.
Can we use the same principle?
So for the for the clustering, right?
So for some applications you will have very specific clusters that are more often more higher priority to solve than other more unlikely clusters.
And maybe you can even do it like on the fly that if I have an application that uses these free.
That you can do it on the fly for these free.
I mean on the flight, I mean even tackling a repair using multiple ontologies right now is still in challenge.

I mean, we've optimized our approximate repair systems such that we can tackle for two ontologies we can tackle most problems in a few minutes, but for three or more ontologies and then it it starts to get tricky.
So doing it on the fly, it's not feasible right now.
Maybe, maybe in the near future, but it's.
It's a good idea to.
To have the the approach done in clusters, yeah, but if I'm an application developer for the next like five years, I'm going to use these five ontologies.
Yeah, I'm willing to wait, like yeah, I'm still satisfied.
Yeah, you know, in a week we can for sure tackle five or six ontologies in and get you.
Results.
